g.text: Matsui et al. Magnesium-Based Intermetallic Anode Active Materials

key parameters which determines the reaction kinetics of the
magnetization/demagnetization process, here we investigated the
The bond valence sum (BVS) mapping is one methodology
to visualize the pathways of the mobile ions in the crystal
structure. The bond-valence parameters for Mg
is commonly taken to a constant value 0.37 Å.

tetrahedral site, via the interstitial octahedral site. The estimated
migration path is in good agreement with the proposed diﬀusion

between two tetrahedral sites of Mg

. Though we still need further validation analyses, all
the results are consistent with the contribution of the fast
mobility to the excellent electrochemical properties of the
In the present study, we investigated the electrochemical
properties of the magnesium-based intermetallic compounds
as alternative anode active material for magnesium batteries.
structure, the electrochemical activity of the Mg
/Ag. The XPS analyses of the Mg
thin ﬁlms showed formations of the MgF
which is the reduction product of the TFSA anion and also
observed at the surface of the magnesium metal thin ﬁlm.
On the other hand, the excellent electrochemical activity of
in three electrolyte solutions: 1 mol L
in DME, suggests that the surface of the Mg
not passivated even with the formation of the MgF
also investigated the stability of the Mg
in ambient atmosphere and in water. The stability tests of the
intermetallics revealed that the formation of the intermetallics is
an eﬀective way to avoid the passivation of the anode surface.
The results also suggested the reversibility of the intermetallic
anode is not only dependent on the passivation-free surface, but
on the fast reaction kinetics. The BVS mapping showed that the
conduction pathway among tetrahedral sites well matches
Here we conclude that the formation of the intermetallics is
eﬀective strategy to avoid the passivation of anode surface,
which hinders the reversible redox reaction. The fast Mg
ion mobility in the solid phase is another key parameter to
obtain the good reversibility applicable to a practical battery
MaM and HK designed the research approach and experiments.
HK carried out the synthesis work. MaM, HK, and DM
carried out the structural analyses and the surface analyses.
HK, NI, and MiM carried out the electrochemical analyses.
MaM wrote the manuscript and all authors discussed the ﬁnal
The present work was ﬁnancially supported by Japan
Science and Technology Agency PRESTO (Grant No.
JPMJPR13CA) and Advanced Low Carbon Technology
Research and Development Program Specially Promoted
Research for Innovative Next Generation Batteries
Many discussions with K. Hanamura, K. Hashimoto, K. Uosaki,
K. Kanamura, Y. Tateyama are gratefully acknowledged. We
thank to T. Ichikawa for his support in the development
of experimental tools. F. Izumi and S. Nishimura kindly
advised us for the usage of the crystal structure analyses
